story: Skyrora has revealed it has identied part of the old Cockenzie Power Station site as a location for its test site.The company, which describes itself as a launch vehicle development company with aims to cater for the growing demand to send small satellites into space, is expected to apply for planning permission from East Lothian Council within the next few months.It held a public consultation on its proposals at the Port Seton Centre today .The Courier revealed last August that Skyrora were looking at East Lothian sites, with the former power station one of the possibilities it was considering to test its rocket engines.Skyrora said that the engine testing would not involve the launching of rockets from the site but would require fuel to be stored on-site to fire up the engines.The UK Space Agency announced that it was investing millions of pounds in a site in Sutherland as the new home of the UKrsquos first spaceport for launching rockets.Skyrora said it was looking for an engine test site within an hour of its Edinburgh offices to give it a local base.It said it had identied part of the former power station site, which was bought by East Lothian Council last year, for its tests.The area being put forward for the site is part of the old coal store.Skyrora said: ldquoThe site will be protected, and special measures will be undertaken to control down the noise impacts to acceptable levels and minimal-period test events.Last year it was revealed that Glasgow produced more space satellites than any other city outside of the USA.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe have been in discussions with Skyrora about the possibility of a temporary lease of land for activities based around engine testing.ldquoA planning application would need to be submitted by Skyrora and considered in due course.

title: dominos-pizza-set-to-come-to-tranent
story: Work has begun to transform the former Indian takeaway at  Bridge Street into a new business, which the Courier understands will be a Dominorsquos.Although a spokesperson from Dominorsquos Pizza declined to comment on whether it was opening in Tranent, signage already approved by East Lothian Council for the premises shows the Dominorsquos name and logo.Tranent is set to become the second town in East Lothian to become home to a Dominorsquos ndash the companyrsquos only other East Lothian outlet currently is on Musselburghrsquos North High Street.

title: dog-walkers-surprise-at-coming-across-octopus-on-beach-at-musselburgh
story: Shona Grieve, , from Longniddry, who now lives in the Fisherrow area, was taking her two-year-old white German shepherd Ivy for her regular walk on the beach when she saw the dead creature.She said: "I was walking at the Fisherrow end of the beach beside the the bowling green."I had thrown Ivys ball and walked to where the ball landed and saw the octopus."I walk the beach every day, sometimes three times a day, with Ivy. In all the years of living by the sea, I have never seen an octopus before. So for me it was a very unusual find. Ivy was a bit curious of it too but more interested in her ball to be fair."She added: "I kept ing to it, to convince myself it was dead which it definitely was."The sea was far out but to reassure myself I managed to put it in a pool of water. This was early on and there was nobody  about to show so I took a picture."I have since been told it is getting more common to find them. I had never seen one before ndash my only rare sighting on the beach was when I was a child and found a small pool of seahorses."An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: "The lesser octopus is not that common but they do turn up occasionally, cast up especially after a storm or following prolonged rough weather."Live specimens have also been found in rock pools at the lowest part of the beach."

title: scotland-footballer-leigh-griffiths-appears-at-speeding-trial
story: Footballer Grfiths, who lives in Wallyford, is alleged to have been caught behind the wheel of his red Range Rover Sport driving at mph while in a mph zone.The -year-old Scotland international is alleged to have been clocked speeding on the A between the Burnshot Flyover and Cammo Road, Edinburgh, on January  last year.On day two of the trial, Edinburgh Justice of the Peace Court heard that the registered keeper of the vehicle at the time of the alleged speeding offence was Nathan Redmond, of Bournemouth.Mr Redmond was contacted by Police Scotland and he informed officers that the driver at the time was former Hibs striker Grfiths.Grfiths was then written to, informing him of the intended prosecution, but he failed to reply.The striker was then written to again by police staff in March last year and eventually replied stating that he had been behind the wheel at the time of the alleged driving offence.A fixed penalty of a pound fine and three penalty points was then offered to Grfiths but was refused.Justice Hillary Stevenson heard from Robert Jefferson, the operator of the mobile camera unit who allegedly caught the footballer speeding, that he had carried out all the necessary and required checks on the equipment.Mr Jefferson, , said that he was ldquosatisfied the camera equipment was ldquotype-approved and the device had been in complete working order that day.Mr Jefferson added that the speed gun used to catch speeding motorists that day was ldquoincredibly accurate and Police Scotland had ldquocomplete confidence in them.The part-heard trial was adjourned for a second time due to witnesses not being cited by the Crown following confusion concerning evidence that had previously been agreed between the prosecution and the footballerrsquos defence team.The footballer was seen joking with court staff prior to his case calling and signed autographs.Grfiths continues to deny driving at mph in a mph limit between the Burnshot Flyover and Cammo Road in Edinburgh on January , .The trial will continue on May .

title: pop-up-bar-plan-at-closed-hotel-in-north-berwick
story: Advertisements have been placed in the windows of the former County Hotel on North Berwick High Street highlighting plans for a new short-term venture called lsquoBeach Hutrsquo.The former -bedroom hotel and bar has been closed for more than six months following the departure of previous licensee Tony Breathnach.The brightly coloured adverts say the venue is looking for full and part-time chefs, managers and waiting staff.A spokeswoman for building owners Star Pubs  Bars said: ldquoWe are keen to reopen The County Hotel as soon as possible.ldquoWe have an experienced and highly talented operator who is interested in launching an exciting pop-up bar and restaurant at the pub in time for the summer.ldquoAs soon as the plans and timings are finalised, we will be able to share more information.Last month, the Courier told how Star Pubs  Bars, part of Heineken UK, had longer-term plans for the premises, which included a major refurbishment.If proposals submitted to East Lothian Council are approved, changes would be made inside the building, with the bar server and public toilets relocated. Outside, a single-storey outbuilding would also be given a new lease of le to form an additional enclosed bar area which would serve food.The company spokesman added: ldquoWe have a long-term vision for The County Hotel and we are developing plans for a major investment programme to create a fresh and exciting pub.ldquoWe are looking for a new licensee to work with us on this great venture. In the meantime, The County Hotel will be reopened with temporary managers in place.Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, said: ldquoThe community council is pleased to note that a pop-up restaurant bar will be opening shortly in The County. High streets are having a tough time at the moment and the community council are thrilled to see initiatives such as pop-up businesses being utilised to prevent units lying empty.We hope that a permanent business can be installed for the longer term however, for the time being, this is fantastic news.

title: honest-lad-and-honest-lass-2019-elected
story: A large crowd, including representatives from the Border towns, gathered to hear the election announcement, which was made from the outside balcony at The Brunton at about pm on Friday.The new Honest Lad and Honest Lass were presented with their medals of office by this yearrsquos sasher PC Dougie Smith, youth community officer.The announcement followed a public election earlier in the day, prior to which the only other candidate for Honest Lad, Michael Morrison, was disbarred from standing due to a pending court case for allegedly using a car without insurance.Aidan, , and Claire, , who was an attendant last year, made their way to an open carriage and, along with the attendant for  Abbie Thomson,  ndash who had stood as an Honest Lass candidate ndash they were piped through the town by the Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band. Volunteers from Musselburgh Sea Cadets had the honour of pulling the carriage.The official party then made its way to Musselburgh Rugby Club to join well-wishers. In keeping with tradition, they danced an eightsome reel with support from th anniversary Attendants Carol Colville and David Banks, and Past Attendant Kier Robinson.Aidan was a pupil at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh before attending St Davidrsquos High School in Dalkeith. On leaving school, he was appointed as an apprentice with Slight Joinery Ltd.Claire was born and brought up in Whitecraig, attending Whitecraig Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools. She works at Pinkie Farm Shop as a general assistant and has been a member of Musselburgh Crusaders Riding Club since she was  years old.Abbie, who attended Campie Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, is currently in her final year studying BScApplied Animal Science at Scotlandrsquos Rural University College and she is due to graduate in July.They will lead the Musselburgh Festival which runs from July  to  with a range of events for all the family on offer as well as traditional favourites such as the sashing of the Honest Lad and Lass, and ever-popular Crusaders Chase.Stefanie Talac, secretary of the Honest Tounrsquos Association, said: ldquoNow that the election has been run and our official party is in place, the committee will be focussing on festival week itself."We have a few changes to the week following feedback in . This year will see the kirkin move back to am in St Michaelrsquos with the sashing taking place at approximately .pm at the Mall.ldquoOur Family Fun Day will now be on Saturday, July , in Pinkie St Peterrsquos playing fields. This event was a huge success last year and we wish to build on that. Lewisvale proved to be constrictive in size and, due to the vast number of families who attended, we felt that a bigger space was necessary for safety.She added: ldquoThe Saturday is also festival day which we wish to make a focus for the townrsquos celebrations. The treasure hunt which has previously taken place on the Monday will now take place on the Wednesday morning.ldquoThese moves look to ensure that we still have family friendly events spread over the week and allow the official party to attend these as well as the ious visits to nurseries, care homes and local businesses throughout the week."Festival week will run from Saturday, July , until Sunday, July , with a wide iety of events to hopefully suit everyone.

title: ready-for-this-years-walk-with-scott-this-weekend
story: The Walk With Scott Foundation is holding its seventh annual walk around East Lothian, raising funds for local causes.The foundation was formed by Tranent man Scott Glynn, who decided just under seven years ago to celebrate his th birthday by walking to the six rugby clubs in the county and putting a collection tin in the bars in each club, before sharing the donations between ious local groups and causes.The walks have been going on every year ever since, with more and more people getting involved ndash and, incredibly, the charity has now raised more than pound, over the years.More than  people will be walking this year, with the route starting at Cockenzie and Port Seton Royal British Legion, heading along to Musselburgh then down the banks of the Esk to Whitecraig, along the old Pencaitland railway, on to Boggs Holdings, up through Butterdean Woods, along the Longniddry railway line to Longniddry, then back along the coast road to Cockenzie, a total of about  miles.A donation page has been set up to help the fundraising effort, and so far the foundation has smashed its pound, target, with more than pound, raised and rising.Scott, , told the Courier: ldquoItrsquos amazing, and we still have time before and after the walk to raise more.ldquoWe have no plans for the money at present ndash itrsquos good to just have some there sosomething comes up, we can use it.The foundation previously has been able to jump into action quickly when helping out East Lothian Foodbank and handing over pound, to the Hollies Day Centre in Musselburgh after it suffered a break-in and theft of its safe.On support for the charity, Scott added: ldquoI think itrsquos because we support local causes and people can see the dference that we make. Now wersquove been around for a while, people know us and know what wersquore about.Scott suffered a health scare two years ago when he was diagnosed with liver cancer and underwent le-saving surgery when he was given a liver transplant.He said: ldquoIrsquom feeling really good and am absolutely ready to go.ldquoI enjoy the walks and am feeling fit and ready. Irsquove been training, as have everyone . Itrsquos great seeing the videos and updates that people send through of them training and working hard.To donate to the charityrsquos efforts visit uk.virginmoneygiving WWSFWalk ndash more information is available from the Walk with Scott Facebook page.

title: talented-amateur-golfer-bob-walkingshaw-remembered
story: Robert lsquoBobrsquo Walkingshaw passed away peacefully at Haddington Care Home last Wednesday after a long illness.Born in Old Craighall, he moved to Salters Road, Wallyford, at the age of  with his father Bob, mother Isa, brother Ian and sisters Elizabeth and Janet.A former pupil of Musselburgh Grammar School, he worked in the ropery at the former Brunton Wire Works in Musselburgh.Mr Walkingshaw took up golf at the age of six.He honed his skills on the fairways of Musselburgh Golf Club, becoming a scratch golfer. He also went on to become a member of Royal Musselburgh Golf Club and Musselburgh Links, The Old Course.In , Mr Walkingshaw, a former Lothians County player, won all four Musselburgh championships: the Monktonhall closed club event Musselburgh Open on the same course Royal Musselburgh Connaught Cup and championship at the Old Links at the racecourse.He also lted the Scottish seniors title twice at amateur level.His sporting prowess did not stop at golf and he became a semi-professional footballer for Stenhousemuir FC. His football career was cut short when he suffered a dislocated hip resulting from a tackle on the pitch and spent six weeks in hospital.A member of Wallyford Bowling Club, he also enjoyed played at the indoor bowling club at Meadowmill.Mr Walkingshaw cared for his mother at their family home on Salters Road.His sister Elizabeth said that he was known as a local ldquolegend in golfing circles, where he was popular and well respected. He was renowned for being ldquoa true gentleman on and off the course.ldquoHe quietly lived his le, she added.Mr Walkingshaw was married twice and has two daughters, Kristi and Debbie, by his second marriage.A devoted grandfather-of-four, he will be sadly missed by the family, including his brother and two sisters.A funeral service takes place tomorrowat Seafield Crematorium at pm. All are welcome to attend.

title: report-of-hare-coursing-near-humbie
story: At about .pm yesterday , officers responded toreports the illegal activity was taking place at farmland there.A maroon or red-coloured Subaru Forrester was seen driving across fields and within this car were two men and three lurcher-type dogs.It is believed that this car has been spotted in the area on a number of occasions and,while police have not identied any crimes at this time, they are keen to trace the occupants of this vehicle as soon as possible to establish why they were in the area.Contact police via  with information or make an anonymous report to Crimestoppers on    quoting incident number  of May .

title: tims-tales-a-lion-that-has-no-roar
story: SPRING is well upon us, my favourite time of year. Finally, after what always seems a long wait, the land is alive and the evenings are long.The colours of this time are a big part of the joy. The blossom and explosion of wild flowers really lts my mood and spirit.A big part of this, for me, is the dandelion. Itrsquos a wild flower which decorates almost everywhere at the moment, creating a carpet of yellow which then transforms into white puffballs of flying lsquowishesrsquo.So many people just see this flower as an annoying weed to be mowed away as soon as it rears its head, but I love the way it keeps cheekily popping up in defiance of our attempts to keep nature at bay. Itrsquos one of our native wild flowers and causes no damage like some real invasive plants can, such as rhododendron.And they benefit our wildle so much. Bees and butterflies feed on them and some birds eat the seeds. But the benefits of the dandelion to humans has also long been recognised.A tea-like drink can be made from the roots and leaves or florets. There are dferent recipes, as the whole plant is edible. You can even make dandelion wine.The sap also contains healing properties which help with a range of ailments, especially skin complaints and issues related to digestion. In fact, herbalists will tell you of a range of health benefits attributed to the dandelion, which is packed with antitoxins and vitamins.And, of course, there are many folklore traditions associated with the flower.One I was reminded of this week when introducing the flower to a class of school children was the belief that you will wet the bedyou touch the petals! There is a small truth in this, as eating the leaves may have a diuretic effect.Making a wish and then blowing the parachute-like wisps which carry the seeds is the stuff of my childhood.Make the wish in secret and the wisps will carry it and help make it true. It is said they can also carry thoughts and love to someone you are missing or thinking about.Other uses include finding out how much you are loved, how many children you may have, or how many years you have left!The dandelion can even forecast the weather, as the puffball will close in on itselfit turns dreich. Another name for it is the lsquoshepherdrsquos clockrsquo, because its flower opens soon after sunrise and closes before the sun sets.And so this week I brought some dandelions into classrooms in a school where I am storytelling.Before I introduced the flowers, I gave them a riddle: ldquoA lion that has no roar, with teeth that do not bite, children who fly away, once yellow has turned to white. They eventually got the answer.The name dandelion, it is believed, comes from the French term lsquodent de lionrsquo meaning lionrsquos tooth, a reference to the teeth-shaped leaves.Then we blew the lsquowishesrsquo in the classroom. I was quite taken with the sense of wonder the children displayed . Many of them caught and kept the lsquowishesrsquo for later. It was so simple, yet so magic.ldquoHave you got more  I was asked.ldquoTherersquos plenty outside you can pick at home time, I told them.But as I left the school, I noticed the road verge I had picked the flowers had just been mowed. All the dandelions were gone, along with the other wild flowers, and it looked lsquonice and neatrsquo.Maybewe paused for a moment to wonder at how amazing this simple and common flower is, and the benefits it gives, we would have a dferent attitude towards it.Eating hand-picked and hand-washed dandelion leaves is one way my children will eat greens. If I mix them into a stir fry, they will be eaten too. These flowers are not just an irritating weed, they are one of naturersquos gts.As I left the school at the end of the day, a child came up to me.ldquoLook, I have a wish I caught, he said, as he carefully unfurled his hand. ldquoIrsquom going to use it to send my love to my granddad.

title: work-set-to-start-to-restore-dunbar-east-beach-to-its-former-glory
story: The once-picturesque sandy beach has lost huge amounts of sand to the tides in recent years.Now, planning permission has been given for a scheme which aims to reinvigorate the beach, which used to be a magnet for tourists.Groynes, a breakwater and rock armour are included in the proposal, which was highlighted by ward councillor Norman Hampshire at a meeting of Dunbar Community Council.Mr Hampshire, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for environment, told the Courier: ldquoWe have been working on this project for some time, trying to get a method where we can attract sand back onto the beach again.ldquoThe consultants who have been looking at it have taken some time to come up with this option: a redesign of the groyne and two breakwaters to prevent [the damage caused] when we have a large sea coming in it damages the main wall and drags sand off the beach. These breakwaters are supposed to prevent that from happening.ldquoIf we can get sand onto the beach, it should stay.The plans, submitted and approved by East Lothian Council, include repairing or replacing an existing groyne on the southern end of the beach that has fallen into disrepair.A rock groyne will be created at the northern end of the beach, opposite the junction with The Vennel, with a concrete groyne towards the south, while a rock breakwater will also be included.The work is split into four sections, with the refurbishment of the existing groyne acting to retain the beach level in the area as it is currently.Secondly, the breakwater, in addition to providing direct protection to a limited section of the defence, will allow an assessment of the capacity for a natural beach to be developed.The groyne at the northern end of the beach will provide protection over part of the northern section of the seawall, with the potential to develop a higher beach in front of the wall.Finally, armour stones will be put in place along Lamer Street to protect the seawall.Mr Hampshire said time had been taken to find the design most likely to boost the beach.But he added: ldquoThere are no guarantees ndash we are fighting against nature here.Mr Hampshire told community councillors he was hopeful work could start ldquoearly summer.Discussions have been ongoing for more than five years regarding what can be done to try to turn the clock back and see the beach looking as it did in the past.Previous suggestions have included bringing sand across from Crail and St Monans in Fe.Mr Hampshire said that had not been ruled out ndash and every option would be explored ndash but it would prove ldquoreally expensive.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, thanked Mr Hampshire for his efforts in bringing the scheme forward.She stressed the importance of the beach and said: ldquoI think East Beach is just part of the place that Dunbar is.ldquoIt has been a holiday destination for a long time and people remember it as a sandy place and a place of leisure.ldquoThis rocky quarry we have now is something that saddens a lot of people.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said they were not yet in a position to reveal the cost of the scheme.She added: ldquoWork identied as helping to tackle erosion concerns on the East Beach will go out to tender with a view to work starting later this year, hopefully before the autumn period.

title: knox-academy-pupils-and-staff-team-up-for-edinburgh-marathon
story: A team of  will represent Knox Academy at the Edinburgh Marathon Festival in the half marathon.Eleven pupils and eight members of staff will all pull on special t-shirts highlighting that they are running for East Lothian Special Needs Playscheme .Alex Redford, a modern studies teacher at the school, said they were looking forward to taking to the start line on May .He said: ldquoS have really tried to embody the school values of Ambition, Respect and Community this year.ldquoThey have worked so very hard on ious fundraisers throughout the year and it has been great to see them really engage with the school values.Pupils Matthew Black, Dylan Brotherston, Isabelle Bowen, Elliot Cochrane, Harry Cunningham, Hana Elder, Adam Fairgrieve, Mateusz Juchniewicz, Max Leveque, Daniel Mackinnon and Lauren Taylor will be joined on the start line by Lana Borwick , Robert Flood , Susanne Fox , Steven Illingworth , Adam Miller , Thomas Salkeld , Suzie Stewartand Mr Redford.Pupil Dylan said: ldquoThere is a little bit of friendly rivalry between the pupils.ldquoObviously, we are all quite competitive with each other and we are quite close friends. We go training together and there is competitiveness there.ldquoWe would expect to finish before the staff ndash except Miss Borwick, she is fairly fit, we would take being beaten by her!Mr Redford came up with the idea of running the .-mile course and got in touch with fellow members of staff.He said: ldquoA couple of years ago, I decided I would run the half marathon.ldquoThis year, I just thought it would be nice, rather than personal charities, to try to tie in with the school.ldquoI wanted to seeanybody wanted to join me, it was a punt in the dark, and wanted to see whether any other staff or S pupils wanted to do it.ldquoEveryone was really keen.Runners will set off from Potterrow in Edinburgh before winding their way through the city and finally to East Lothian.S pupil Dylan said training was going well and told the Courier how he had been inspired by the charity, which provides full-day playschemes during school holidays for East Lothian children aged five to  with a wide range of special needs or disabilities.He said: ldquoObviously, the charity is really worthwhile. My personal motivation is seeing the work the charity has done with pupils in the school.Exhausted, athletes will cross the finish line at the playing fields at Pinkie in Musselburgh.Dylan added: ldquoIt is nice to be able to run in an environment that is familiar.ldquoHopefully, a few staff and pupils will be coming to support us at the end. When we have done these runs in the past, the support the community offers is brilliant and spurs you on.ldquoIt is nice to be in a local environment.In total, the Knox Academy teachers and pupils are aiming to raise more than pound,, with each runner tasked with collecting at least pound of sponsorship.Donate at justgiving fundraising knoxacademy

title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-conservative-candidate-craig-hoy
story: In a -year career in the media and in business, he worked in Edinburgh, London and Asia.He said: ldquoLocal people want a councillor who will focus on everyday issues that matter to everyone in the ward."While the SNP obsesses about another isive independence referendum, I am focusing on local services such as schools, social care, leisure facilities and roads. I will work hard to protect the interests of rural communities."I want to see our High Street flourish and will explore efforts to increase peak-time parking. I will also support action to combat anti-social behaviour in the town centre and beyond."We are welcoming many new residents and I will work hard to ensure schools, doctors surgeries and leisure services are expanded."I will fight SNP Government budget cuts, which this year resulted in East Lothian Council being forced to scrap free music tuition for our children and led to large council tax rises."Regardless of how you normally vote, please lend me your support to stop the SNP winning."If elected, I will be a councillor for everyone in the ward.

title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-liberal-democrat-candidate-stuart-crawford
story: His three children all went to school here.He said: ldquoI joined the Scottish Liberal Democrat Party because it is broad-minded, tolerant and inclusive, and above all  believes in decentralisation of political power: local issues demand solutions decided at the local level."I have worked for myself since my Army days and continue to do so, as a political and media consultant and freelance journalist."Previous involvement in local issues includes the setting up of the Sidegate Residentsrsquo Association in the early noughties to campaigningagainst an unsympathetic development on Briery Bank. I have also been recently appointed a trustee of St Maryrsquos Pleasance Garden."East Lothian has been good to me and my family, and now I have the time and energy to give something back."I believe I have a good grasp of what folk tell me needs doing and,elected, representing and serving those in the ward to the best of my ability, and not indulging in petty party politicking, will be my main and only focus.

title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-labour-candidate-neal-black
story: He said: ldquoI am proud to live in the ward with my family. I am involved in my community in this way because I care passionately about helping to get the best for local people."We have great schools and other excellent public services which I will defend from sustained Scottish Government cuts."I want to ensure we keep supporting local communities by constantly improving all our vital local services."I am also committed to working with local communities and my Labour colleagues on the council to make our area an even better place to live. title: haddington-lammermuir-by-election-everything-you-need-to-know
story: A by-election is taking place following the resignation of Conservative councillor Brian Small earlier this year.Voters in the ward will have a choice of five candidates when they go to the polls, with the successful candidate announced the following day.Already, the ward is represented by three councillors: Shamin Akhtar, John McMillanand Tom Trotter .They will be joined by a fourth councillor.Neal Black , Stuart Crawford , Lorraine Glass , Craig Hoyand David Sissonare all standing for election.Voting takes place between am and pm next Thursday, with polling stations at Aubigny Sports Centre, Haddington Athelstaneford Village Hall Bolton Village Hall Fletcher Hall, East Saltoun Garvald Village Hall Gford Village Hall Humbie Village Hall Morham Village Hall Ormiston Community Centre and Trevelyan Hall, Pencaitland.The by-election will use the Single Transferable Votesystem, where voters can rank candidates in order of preference rather than a single cross. title: work-about-to-start-on-second-platform-at-dunbar-railway-station
story: Engineers start work on site on Tuesday and are beginning by establishing a project office and compound ahead of the start of construction work at the station.The pound million scheme will deliver a new -metre second  and a fully accessibly steel footbridge, with lts also included for disabled access.Throughout May, work will take place to clear vegetation and redundant buildings and track to make way for the new infrastructure.Construction work on the project will be ongoing from until early next year, with the new  expected to be operational from the end of November.Matthew Spence, Network Rail route delivery director for Scotland, said: ldquoThe new  will mean extra capacity at Dunbar and create opportunities for more services to stop in the future.ldquoThe new infrastructure, which will be fully accessible, will also include a choice of materials and paint colours that are designed to be considerate to the historic station building.The new  will provide increased capacity and improve operational flexibility as currently all northbound and southbound services have to use the same .Northbound stopping services will use the new  once it is constructed and it will also allow train companies on the East Coast Main Line to operate more services on the route in the future.Currently, there are no plans for a pedestrian link to the new  from the south side of the town, although East Lothian Council is keen to see that changed in the future.Two public drop-in sessions were held earlier this year in Dunbar to give members of the public the chance to see the plans for the , near the townrsquos Salisbury Walk.More information on the project can be found at networkrail DunbarStation

title: bridge-over-north-berwick-railway-line-due-to-re-open
story: The bridge over the railway line at Ware Road - where traffic lights are to be installed -has been closed for several days to allow project excavation work to take place.An East Lothian Council spokesperson told the Courier that the first phase of the bridge works, which has led to its closure, was due to be completed today ."To allow the work to be undertaken safely, the bridge has been closed to traffic and pedestrians, with advisory signs in place," said the spokesperson."It ishoped that the first phase,which involved excavation work and the installation of ducting for the traffic signals, will be completed today."The second phase of the works - the installation of the traffic lights - will then start and is expected to take a few days."The bridge will be open during this [second phase] work with traffic management in place," added the spokesperson.The bridge is a key route to school for children and used regularly by motorists as it is the only crossing over the railway line in North Berwick.But its narrowness has led to pedestrian safety concerns as it does not have a raised pavement.East Lothian Council told the Courier last month thatthe introduction of "controlled traffic signals"wouldaid "safer crossing opportunities for pedestrians" - though fears have been raised that the lights will cause a backlog of traffic on Ware Road itself and Old Abbey Road.

title: joanna-blythman-for-me-the-cooking-acumen-and-the-prices-just-dont-stack-up
story: I suppose Merienda, located a short hop away, reflects the Scran and Scallie dfusion effect: an assumption that local wallets can take a serious hit, even for a pretty informal meal. I may have missed it, but I canrsquot see a bottle of wine under pound. Thankfully wersquore concentrating on the food: ldquoMediterranean-inspired small plate dining using the finest artisan Scottish ingredients. Our loquacious waiter makes a song and dance of the menu, down on his hunkers, interacting with us like a needy actor in a very small theatre whorsquos desperate for the people in the front row to clap.I could do without playing the bit part to the lead actor, but my mounting irritation will wash off methe food lives up to the script. I try not to be disconcerted by the prominence of what looks to be microwaves in the kitchen. I try not to be irked by the lazy metallic clatter of cutlery being dried then dropped into their drawer.Our first couple of dishes are of supermarket deli standard, heavy, salty sun-dried tomato bread that doesnrsquot have the airy texture to merit the description ldquofocaccia with a reasonable basil oil to dunk it in, and oddly greyish, matt-looking slices of what strike me as machine-cut ham- apparently  months-aged Serrano- with fridge-cold ldquooven cured plum tomato. ldquoOven cured  Isnrsquot that an oxymoron  But Irsquom still hopeful. I detect more linguistic imprecision with the ldquoAberdeen Angus carpaccio, aged Pecorino, and vinaigrette Raffaelli. Carpaccio is Italian traditionally dressed with good quality extra virgin olive oil and lemon. This rendition is so vinegary it obliterates the flavour of the meat, kills the little wine wersquore drinking stone dead, and the oil is so straw-pale it reminds me of refined vegetable oil.ldquoThessaloniki chicken with walnut and apricots intrigues us, and the free-range bird comes from estimable St Brides, so Irsquom up for that. The dried fruit and nuts, mixed with feta, form a stuffing, some undercooked pancetta or streaky bacon puts a pink collar around each slice. Itrsquos pleasant enough. And apart from the decorative leaves of wild garlic that have wilted and clamped themselves to the heated plates, therersquos a lot to be said for the herb crusted Biggar lamb. Its succulent, rosy flesh looks lovely and works well with a suave, moss green, wild garlic pureacutee.Restaurant review: Loch Leven Seafood Cafe, Onich, by Fort WilliamWe give the ldquoseared asparagus in its pretentiously named ldquolemon and honey emulsion a chance, but it tastes bitter. And sorry, Irsquod say that honey does nothing for asparagus. I finally part company with Merienda when the purple sprouting broccoli in Roquefort sauce are placed before us, five spindly, fibrous stalks, in what might have been a sound blue cheese sauceit werenrsquot for the cooking water thatrsquos leached in to it. pound for this, thats pound. a stalk. On another plate, three small mouthfuls of roast monkfish cheek served with ldquocourgette ribbons that look as dated as radish roses, sit in a puny, faint-hearted ldquolobster bisque that barely tastes of shellfish, let alone the said crustacean.Desserts arrive slowly, mainly because our server is performing at other tables. ldquoBurnt cheesecake  Itrsquos meant to be cooked at c to form a ldquobark. Actually, it just tastes like deadly plain baked white cheese. Weird though it is to hear myself saying this, it needs more sugar. It comes with ldquocaramel Grand Marnier mandarins, a singed take on those tinned segments I adored as a child. We canrsquot taste the orange brandy. Once again, Meriendarsquos idea of a common dish, rhubarb fool this time, doesnrsquot correspond to mine. This is a stingy spoonful of under-sweetened fruit, topped with ultra-plain cream almost whipped to butter consistency, and chunky biscuit crumbs that are hard enough to crack a dental crown on.Maybe well-heeled Stockbridge has embraced Merienda. For me, the cooking acumen and the prices just donrsquot stack up.Merienda,  N W Circus Place, Edinburgh   Food:  Atmosphere:  Service:  Value for money:  Joanna BlythmanGuild of Food Writers Food Writer of the Year

title: in-pictures-biggest-ever-all-under-one-banner-march-for-independence-in-glasgow
story: The All Under One Banner event set off from Kelvingrove Park at .pm and passed through the city before finishing at Glasgow Green for a rally.Some people joined in with the crowds of marchers waving Saltires as the event passed along the city streets.Police estimated that -, people were at Glasgow Green for the rally, where a number of speakers and musical acts appeared on a stage in the park.First Bus said it would endeavour to keep a service running within the city centre throughout the afternoon but warned there will be disruption and ersions to services.#Read more:Tens of thousands march through Glasgow in support of Scottish independenceTraffic management was also be in place around the M, with the closure of the westbound carriageway from the junction  on-slip at Townhead and a lane closure in place through to junction  off-slip at Charing Cross.An organiser for the All Under One Banner event said: "The people of Scotland demand that Scotland regains full independence from London rule and so we march in our tens of thousands at Glasgow this Saturday to declare this so, and to state that it is we the people who are in charge, not the English parliament  miles away."Scotland is on the rise and the end of the UK is nigh as we are taking our country back, and we are taking it now."Check out our gallery above for pictures of the march.Pictures by Colin Mearns.

title: the-10-most-interesting-gardens-to-visit-in-scotland
story: Dunoon, Argyll PA QUIN ITS magnicent mountainside setting, Benmore, which is one of the four gardens of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh , is steeped in history and surrounded by dramatic scenery. The gardenrsquos  acres are home to a world-famous collection of plants from regions ranging from the Orient and the Himalaya to North and South America.With more than , plants of around  species, arranged by botanical grouping or geographic region, the garden has been described as a ldquoliving textbook of the genus Rhododendronrsquorsquo. One of the favourites at Benmore is a mighty R. sinogrande discovered by plant collectors George Forrest in China in .Visitors enter Benmore through an avenue of -year-old giant redwoods, which has been described as the best entrance to any botanic garden in the world. Other trees of interest include Douglas fir, beeches from Chile and New Zealand, monkey puzzles, western hemlock and Scots pine.A microcosm of the Bhutanese mountains has been created on a south-facing slope at Benmore, where visitors can rest in the pavilion and look out over the magnicent landscape. A Chilean area is also rapidly developing, and when mature, visitors will be able to imagine they are walking through a Chilean rainforest with spiky green parasols of tall monkey puzzle trees.Website: www.rbge.org.ukPhone:  Opening times: am to pm April to September am to pm March and OctoberAdmission costs: Adult: pound., concession: pound., child: freeunder :Six Scottish summer walksAttadale GardensSouth side of Loch Carron on A, opposite village of Lochcarron IV YXAttadale Gardens was developed by artist Nicky Macpherson after serious storms brought down its huge old trees at the end of s. Using the mountains as a backdrop and with the pond already present, over  years she has created a wonderful garden designed to be enjoyed by locals and visitors from further afield.It was a chance for a new beginning with over  new trees planted, and a wonderful water garden created along the entrance drive. It is richly planted with water-loving plants from around the world huge gunnera pretty, colourful primula irises and many more reflected in black pools with little Monet-style bridges to wander over.There is a tremendous selection of very old rhododendrons and sweet-smelling azaleas at this time of year many of these were planted before the First World War and continue to flourish. Two Wollemi pines flourish above the upper path amongst the rhododendrons.Attadale also boasts a Japanese garden, which was created to solve problems of regular flooding and showcases many traditional Japanese garden features. An impressive kitchen garden provides a contrast with rows of beautully kept vegetables.Website: www.attadalegardensTelephone:  Opening times: .am - .pmAdmission costs: pound. Adults, pound. Seniors and pound ChildBranklyn Garden, National Trust for Scotland, Dundee Road, Perth PH BBBranklyn Garden was created by John and Dorothy Renton in the s in the grounds of their home. Forty years later, in a labour of love, they had created what one expert described as ldquothe finest two acres of private garden in the country. Over  species from all over the world now flourish here, nearly half of them are direct descendants of the Rentonrsquos own plants.Today, Branklyn is owned and maintained by the National Trust for Scotland, having been passed on in , but still retains the feel of an intimate, personal garden. The responsibility of the current team of gardeners is to maintain the legacy of the Rentons, whilst ensuring the garden and its extensive collection of rare plants remains current in the st century.Visitors can be treated to a feast of ied plant species from February through to October, beginning with colourful displays of erythroniums, rhododendrons and trilliums in spring, whilst the giant lily, Cardiocrinum giganteum, entrances visitors during the summer.Dorothy Renton built up a great relationship with Himalayan plant collectors, and as a result, the garden contains many of their seed introductions, from trees and shrubs, to the famous Meconopsis. Some of the original introductions share the same bed as modern cultis and Branklyn currently holds a Plant Heritage, National Collection of these plants.Website: www.nts.org.uk BranklynGardenTelephone:  Opening times: Daily am - pm . Tea Room open am to pmAdmission costs: NTS members free of charge, Adults pound., Concessions pound., Family ticket pound.:Six Scottish summer walksLogan Botanic GardenPort Logan, Dumfries  Galloway DG NDLogan Botanic Garden, located on the southwest tip of Scotland, is one of the four gardens of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburghand is home to plant treasures from South and Central America, Southern Africa and Australasia, all rarely seen in the United Kingdom.The warming influence of the Gulf Stream helps to create lsquoScotlandrsquos most exotic gardenrsquo. Visitors can walk through groves of eucalyptus and palm trees or stand in the shade of the awesome rhubarb-like gunnera.At this time of year, carpets of trilliums, exotic rhododendrons and many other species are in all their glory, with many providing colour well into autumn. Hardy perennials such as Argyranthemum, Diascia and Penstemon provide a painterrsquos palette of colour around the walled garden.The elegant Logan conservatory, the first carbon-free glasshouse of its kind in the UK, provides a succession of colours from a large collection of Pelargoniums, stunning Proteas and Cape Primroses, which have a mass of lavender, trumpet-like flowers.The conservatory frontage is ablaze with fiery red Cannas that create a sub-tropical feel all summer long with its banana-like foliage. It is incredible that this lives outdoors all year round at Logan.Website: www.rbge.org.ukTelephone:  Opening times: am ndash pm dailyAdmission costs: Adults pound children free of Scotlandrsquos most gruesome castlesCambo GardensThe Stables Visitor Centre, Cambo, Kingsbarns, Fe KY QDCambo boasts a large, .-acre walled garden, and its ied topography allows visitors to enjoy vistas throughout the garden of the signicant collection of perennials and shrubs, nestled within the ancient fruit trees, old roses and tender coastal loving species.A key feature at Cambo is the canalised burn. It meanders through the gardens, allowing visitors to enjoy the tumbling water as it cascades through the planting, with views to pools and waterfalls from a series of bridges that span its .Camborsquos summer perennial plantings are breathtakingly beautul. Teaming with tremendous colour, the garden is at one of its peaks in the summer, when the plantings come alive and are joined by a signicant collection of trees. Showstoppers include the double herbaceous borders, with their perennials and grasses peaking perfectly together.The Cambo North American Prairie is unique in Scotland, a substantial planting of bold and beautul North American Prairie species. Planted in  and grown from seed, this enchanting bed of Echinaceas, mingling with Prairie Bergamot, an array of asters, vivid yellow daisies and sweeping grasses, mesmerise visitors as they walk through the winding paths filled with butterflies and become immersed in its exquisiteness.Website: www.camboheritagetrust.org.ukTelephone:  Admission costs: pound. for adults, children and carers are free. RHS free entry on Wednesdays. Coach parties welcome.Opening Hours: Everyday am-pm:Six Scottish summer walksRoyal Botanic Garden Edinburgha Inverleith Row, Edinburgh EH LRThe Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh , which will celebrate its th anniversary in , is one of the worldrsquos leading Botanic Gardens. Established in  as a medicinal plant or physic garden at Holyrood, the garden moved several times within Edinburgh until in  it arrived at its present site in Inverleith.Today, within the  acres of the garden and Living Collection, visitors can see over , plant species and over , plants from more than  countries, including one of the largest collections of Chinese plants outside China. Garden highlights include the world-famous Rock Garden, Chinese Hillside, Woodland Garden, Queen Motherrsquos Memorial Garden and Herbaceous Border.Just a mile from the centre of Edinburgh, the garden is a delight throughout the seasons. At this time of year, spectacular rhododendrons are in bloom amongst other spring flowering plants. On colder days, visitors can discover ten dferent climatic zones within the glasshouses, from steamy tropics to arid desert. The glasshouses are home to , exotic plants from across the globe including the largest cultivated collection of Vireya rhododendrons in the world.Website: rbge.org.ukTelephone:   Opening times: Open daily from am to pm March to September. See website for winter hoursAdmission costs: Admission to the garden is free but charges to glasshouses apply - pound adult, pound concessions, under s free.Scotlands  greatest drives revealedThe Quoy of Houton  Orkney Garden FestivalOrphir, Kirkwall KW RDNeolithic wonders of the world, the sunken fleets of Scapa Flow and some of the most amazing sea scapes in the world come to mind when the Orkney islands are mentioned in conversation, yet it is also home to the UKrsquos most northerly garden festival.From th to th July, gardeners from across the UK will arrive on the islands to enjoy  open gardens and illustrated talks by Beechgrove presenters Carole Baxter and Lesley Watson. Cha judge Dougal Philip will be joining in the fun along with world renowned plantsmen and authors Ken Cox and Jackie Bennett.It all started at The Quoy of Houton six years ago after Kevin Critchlow, a local dry stone waller, underwent a -hour operation to remove a massive brain tumour. The garden opened to raise funds for the charity Friends of Neuro ward ARI, which his we Caroline founded. Friendly islander gardeners joined in and now Orkney is well and truly on the horticultural map.Several of the gardens have featured on BBC Beechgrove Garden and The Quoy of Houton is listed in the UKrsquos top  coastal gardens. This walled gem is a panoramic garden, which is designed to lead the eye to the amazing sea views. It is also home to an ever-expanding collection of perennial geraniums including Alan Bremnars Orkney geraniums.Website: www.orkneybedandbreakfast.org.ukTelephone:  Opening times  admission: Open by arrangement outside of festival by donationDawyck Botanic GardenStobo, Scottish Borders EH JUNestled in the Scottish Borders, the five-star Dawyck Botanic Garden enjoys a continental climate in which an abundance of plant species can thrive. The -acre landscape is one of the four gardens of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburghand is renowned for its seasonal displays, including treasures from Nepal, China, Chile and more.At this time of year, daffodils, bluebells, rhododendrons, azaleas and meconopsiscarpet the banks of Dawyckrsquos Scrape Burn.Dawyck is also home to one of Scotlandrsquos finest tree collections including some of Britainrsquos oldest and tallest trees. It is this impressive tree collection that attracts many visitors to the garden throughout the year. Its oldest tree is a European silver firplanted in  during the reign of Charles II. Other species of note are the Douglas fir, named after the intrepid plant collector David Douglas, Lawson cypress and giant Sierra redwood.Here, visitors can enjoy themed trails and discover the Heron Wood Reserve and Cryptogamic Sanctuary, the worldrsquos first reserve for mosses, liverworts, lichens and fungi.Web: www.rbge.org.ukTel:  Opening times: Open daily am to pm in April to September. See website for winter hoursAdmission costs: pound adult, pound concession, under s free.Inverewe Garden, National Trust for ScotlandPoolewe, Achnasheen, Ross-shire IV LGNational Trust for Scotlandrsquos most northerly property, Inverewe Garden, is well-famed for its range of rhododendrons, with flowers to be found somewhere in the garden every month of the year. Meandering through the garden on this remote stretch of coastline is a paradise of unusual and wonderful plants, where the unexpected greets you at every corner.Head Gardener Kevin Ballrsquos three favourite rhododendrons are: Rhododendron lindleyi with its glorious large, trumpet-shaped flowers of the purest white and which emit a strong, sweet-spicy fragrance, Rhododendron lsquoLoderi King Georgersquo with its scented, white, lily-like flowers that open in tall trusses from bright pink buds, and lastly, the honeysuckle-scented Rhododendron luteum, which makes an excellent garden plant because of its long flowering season and ease of cultivation.Lucky visitors to Inverewe may have a chance to spot Scotlandrsquos Big  in wildle: red squirrel, red deer, otter, seal and golden eagle. A newly revamped visitor centre and cafeacute add to the destination experience ndash and coming up next season is a wonderful new observation tower to view the garden from a completely new perspective.Inverewe also has busy events programme, including the Highlands and Islands Plant Festival , the Scottish Rock Garden Festival , and a wide range of art exhibitions in its new Sawyer Gallery. For more information on events, visit the gardenrsquos website.Website: nts.org.uk invereweTelephone:  Opening times: .ndash. until  May, then .ndash.  Junndash Aug. See website for autumn hours, house, cafeacute and shop opening hoursAdmission costs: Adult- pound., family- pound., single adult family - pound., concession - pound.The Japanese Garden at CowdenUpper Hillfoot Road, Dollar, Clackmannanshire FK PLThe Japanese Garden was established by Ella Christie of Cowden Castle. At the turn of the last century, she ed from an expedition to the Orient inspired by her tours of the magnicent gardens.As might be expected from one of the first western women to visit Khiva and Samarkand and to meet the Dalai Lama, Ellarsquos approach to developing the garden was trailblazing. She chose a female designer ndash the gted Taki Handa ndash to create the seven-acre site,  miles north-west of Edinburgh. It is the first and only one of such scale to be accredited to a woman and it remains a unique, authentic bridge between Scottish and Japanese culture.In , it was described by Professor Jijo Suzuki, th hereditary head of the Soami School as lsquoThe most important Japanese Garden in the Western Worldrsquo.Vandalised in the s, it has now been brought back to le by Professor Masao Fukuhara, best known for winning the Gold Medal at the Cha Flower Show and for the restoration of the Japanese gardens at Kew and Tatton.Cowden has been managed by a charity since  and there is plenty to see, including two new bridges, the dry garden, original and new planting and the antique stone lanterns. Disabled and primary carer: free.About Discover Scottish GardensDiscover Scottish Gardens is the countryrsquos national garden tourism group, which aims to put Scottish gardens, nurseries and related businesses on the tourist map. title: cruachan-dam-construction-pictures-how-a-mountain-became-a-power-station
story: Amid breathtaking Highland scenery, Ben Cruachan stands tall the highest point in Argyll and Bute and one of a range of jagged peaks stretching between Loch Etive and Loch Awe.Rock solid and stone cold, it weathered the elements unchanged and unchallenged for  million years.Or, at least it did until  years ago this summer, when men with gelignite and ingenious plans set about slicing it open, blasting a huge hole in its belly and drawing power from deep within its rocky soul.Those who witnessed the engineering and construction miracle that produced the worldrsquos first high-level reversible pumped storage scheme for generating hydroelectricity say the dirt, noise and scale of excavating its innards felt like stepping into the jaws of hell.But for Scots who had rapidly come to rely on flicking a switch for instant electricity, the newly constructed pound. million Cruachan Power Station brought power to the people in hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses.Construction work on surely the most ambitious manmade project Scotland has ever seen began in mid-, and continued even after its official opening by the Queen in .But while half a century has passed since it first sent hydroelectricity to the National Grid, todayrsquos renewable energy landscape means the almost instant power supplied by the "hollow mountain" is required more than ever.For should renewable power sources fail and the nationrsquos lights go out, it will be Cruachanrsquos steadfast and sure turbines and generators that will be called upon to produce the power that will restart essential services across the land.And, such is the hydro plantrsquos ability to produce clean and almost instant power, its current operators have a breathtaking wish list to one day dramatically increase its output and even blast again into that ancient rock to create ldquoCruachan Two.ldquoWersquore thinking about it and we would love to do it, says Ian Kinnaird, head of hydro at Cruachan Power Stationrsquos owner, Drax.ldquoItrsquos so expensive but there is lobbying of Government going on to demonstrate the value and how well it compliments renewables. We need to find a mechanism to make it financially viable to build.Twenty miles south of Oban and carved from solid bedrock, Cruachanrsquos cavernous machine hall sits km inside the mountain. The size of a football pitch, it is ft high, nearly ft long and spacious enough to accommodate a seven-storey building.Conceived by hydroelectricity pioneer Sir Edward MacColl, and engineered by Glasgow-based James Williamson  Partners, its construction saw , cubic metres of rock and soil scooped from its innards. The task involved around , workers, many drawn from Ireland by the prospect of high wages, who swapped home for a makesht camp and back-breaking, filthy -hour shts.Today the cavern they chiselled from the guts of Cruachan is pristine, home to four generator sets powered by water from a reservoir and Loch Awe, capable of delivering a total of  megawattsof electricity ndash enough to supply more than , homes ndash and flexible enough to power up within seconds, reaching full pumping speed in a mere eight minutes.For the young Kenny Omond, a Heriot-Watt University electronics engineering student looking for a summer job in , Ben Cruachanrsquos exposed innards were both terrying and mesmerising, with conditions that surely no ldquoCruachan Two project would ever endure.ldquoIt was like Dantersquos Inferno, says Omond, , from Livingston. ldquoThe machine hall was probably as big as St Giles Cathedral, with little tunnels spinning off.ldquoThere were huge dump trucks going up and down these little corridors. The tyres were eight feet high and the tunnels so narrow that you had to flatten yourself against the walls as they rolled by.It was an age, he recalls, when safety gear largely consisted of a hard hat and crossed fingers.ldquoThere was the peaceful beauty of Loch Awe, but inside the mountain the noise was unbearable, Omond shudders. ldquoThere were boxes of gelignite just lying around.As well as the cavernous machine room, construction involved km of tunnels including two that stretch m and at -degree angles, and a m buttressed concrete gravity dam some m up the mountainside. It was not for the faint-hearted  men lost their lives, hundreds of others were injured.Tunnel Tiger Ian MacLean, , of Taynuilt, was a young joiner tasked with shuttering the machine roomrsquos giant horseshoe-shaped concrete roof.ldquoDump trucks came from nowhere, theyrsquod appear  feet in front of you. The noise was sore on your ears, like a vibration that would go on and on, he says.ldquoMe and my mate were working in a shaft that went up to the dam when a chap fell straight down. The guys said afterwards that the oil skins he was wearing had basically held him together.ldquoIt made you wonder what you were doing there.Handsome wages provided balance to the gruelling work and the gnawing fear.ldquoYou got an extra shilling an houryou were working in the tunnel,   moreyou were in the shaft, adds MacLean. ldquoAt the end of the week, Irsquod have pound in my pocket ndash my father in those days was only earning pound.Built to support Scotlandrsquos nuclear power stations, Cruachan was intended to operate for short bursts to help juggle increases in demand. These days it is increasingly operating day as well as night.ldquoThe loss of coal-fired plants and the increase of more intermittent renewables such as wind and solar has meant the role of Cruachan and other stations like it have become more important than the original concept, explains Kinnaird.ldquoWe are seeing a changing landscape. Historically we were generating during the day, absorbing energy and pumping up to the reservoir at night.ldquoNowitrsquos windy during the day, we can be pumping during the day to save energy so the National Grid isnrsquot having to pay wind farms not to generate.ldquoWhen the wind dies down, we can release that energy back to the grid so itrsquos not being lost.In recent years, two of Cruachanrsquos four generator motor sets were virtually renewed and output boosted from MW each to MW. Environmental studies are under way to assess the impact of further excavation of the mountain.ldquoWe have outline plans for Cruachan Two, but the capital costs of excavating inside a mountain and building another plant are very, very high, says Kinnaird. ldquoBut wersquore thinking about it. And we would love to do it.

title: why-superheroes-are-box-office-superstars
story: Within a few days of its release, the film is in the top  highest-grossing movies of all time , in the same elite bracket as Avatar, Titanic and Jurassic World.The three-hour-long film, whose many stars include Scarlett Johansson, Chris Hemsworth, Chris Evans, Robert Downey Jnr, Mark Ruffalo and Jeremy Renner, has broken some box-office records, pulling in .bn in global receipts.In fact, of the current  worldwide top-grossing films ever, listed on the website Box Office Mojo, no fewer than nine are superhero movies: Avengers: Infinity War, Marvels The Avengers, Avengers: Age of Ultron, Black Panther, Avengers: Endgame, Incredibles , Iron Man , Captain America: Civil War and Aquaman.The sprawling and intensely lucrative Marvel Cinematic Universehas included such films as the Iron Man trilogy, the Avengers films mentioned above, Ant-Man, Black Panther, The Incredible Hulk and Captain Marvel, which starred Brie Larson."This storytelling strand, the Infinity series, has been going since Iron Man, in ," says Alison Rowat, the Heralds film writer, "so a whole generation has grown up with these tales."The films have given audiences traditional things, like heroes to care for. Theyve given them everything from comedy to tragedy and straight-up drama. Above all, theyve given people a reason to keep coming back and find out what happens next."Theyre very clever in that they are standalone films, but with links. One film will throw up a strand that another picks up on. Fans love that kind of thing: it makes them feel asthey are part of a club, insiders.Like other critics, Rowat has noted the attention to detail in these superhero films. "The most successful of these films are made by what you might call fan-boys who are steeped in the genre."In the new Endgame film, theres a lovely scene where all the Avengers are getting together again, and they go to Thors home. In the background you see this bottle of amber liquid and you think, Can that really be a bottle of Irn-Bru  And it is. Its that sort of attention to detail that makes you realise why these films are so beloved by the fans."The directors of Endgame, brothers Joe and Anthony Russo, have been taken aback by the success of the film. ldquoWe were definitely surprised. We knew the movie was good but you can never predict something like this, Anthony said last week. ldquoWith this kind of runaway success, the phrase standing on the shoulders of giants comes to mind, because the MCU has been building for so long. The audience has a depth of emotion for these characters."Not everyone, however, is in love with the MCU or with superhero films in general.Jodie Foster, for one. ldquoI worked  years to become a director, she has said. ldquoIt took me this long, and Irsquom going to make a superhero movie  I donrsquot think so.As Empire film magazine pointed out a few months ago, there are those who see Marvel Studios and the MCU as the epitome of everything that is wrong with modern blockbusters, and "rail against the homogenisation of mass entertainment, and lay the blame for all the copycat shared universes and interlinked franchises that have sprung up in its wake."But that," Empire went on, "almost wilfully ignores the creative success of these movies. Funny, thrilling, laced with great character work, a Marvel Studios movie ... is as surefire a guarantee of a good time at the movies as its possible to get."Fairy-tales for grown-upsTHE late Stan Lee upended the comic book industry in the s, creating Spider-Man, the X-Men, the Fantastic Four and most of the Avengers, amongst other lastingly popular characters.In a  TEDx Gateway video talk, he said: "For me, superheroes will always spark the imagination of people around the world, regardless of their background, because I think that people are always looking for something that represents the ideal person or the ideal situation."Almost all of us loved fairy-tales when we were young. Just remember stories of giants and witches and wizards and monsters and things that were so colourful and bigger than le. But then, you get a little older, and youre too old to read fairy-tales, but you never outgrow your love of that type of story. Andyou think about it, superhero stories today are really like fairy-tales for grown-ups. The characters are bigger than le, just like in fairy-tales. They have the same type of super-powers some can fly, some are extra-strong, some can be invisible...."Game of thronesCOULD Avengers: Endgame go on to topple Avatar from its .bn all-time box-office record  It is just possible.As The Hollywood Reporter said this week: "After making history and obliterating records across the globe, Avengers: Endgame is destined to become only the fth movie to clear  billion at the worldwide box office, not adjusted for inflation."The looming question now: Does the Disney and Marvel superhero pic have a shot at dethroning Avatars . billion and becoming the top-grossing movie of all time worldwide  Box office analysts say that would be a tough feat, but they arent ruling anything out after Endgame opened to a record-shattering . billion globally, including an unheard-of  million in North America and  million overseas. The international tally includes an all-time high of . million in China."Longer, better LIKE Superman and Spider-Man, Batman has proved irresistible over the decades to film-makers.Batman himself was the subject of four successful films between  and : Batman and Batman Returns, both directed by Tim Burton and with Michael Keaton as the caped crusader, squaring up to first Jack Nicholson then Danny DeVito Joel Schumachers Batman Forever, starring Val Kilmer and Schumachers Batman and Robin, with George Clooney and Chris ODonnell in the title roles.More recently, Batman was revived to considerable acclaim by Christopher Nolan, with Christian Bale taking the lead role in Batman Begins , The Dark Knightand The Dark Knight Rises . The last film is currently th in Box Office Mojos all-time list of worldwide top-grossing hits.As superhero films become longer and more ambitious, so too do they reflect the staggering improvements in computer graphics, with entire new virtual worlds opening up on the big screen and captivating millions of movie-goers. But there are film enthusiasts who argue that something has been lost amidst the spectacular special effects."That tends to ide people, actually," observes Alison Rowat." Youll get people who say the older superhero movies are the best ones because they were straightforward - the guy rescues the girl and they live happily ever after."Not everyone has got the patience to sit through them. Some think that the current crop maybe take themselves too seriously. They still do have their faults. Theres always a big fight scene at the end, which can be interminable."They keep getting longer and longer, too. Avengers: Endgame is three hours long and that is not to everyones taste either. I went to an am screening of Endgame and the cinema was pretty busy, but it was interesting that the three-hour run-time had quite a few people calling for aof the old intermissions."In the future ..ITS safe to say we have not yet seen the last of the superhero movie event. "It can definitely go on because they have generated their own audience and they can keep going back to them," says Alison Rowat. "But its like everything  - you need to be careful not to kill the goose that lays the golden eggs. Already, yoursquove got older cinema-goers turning up at cinemas and thinking, oh no, not another superhero movie. But its all about constantly reinventing the genre. The great thing that is coming out of this Avengers series is Black Panther. That is very exciting and will get people coming back for more. The same goes for some of the women superheroes that theyve got coming along too. That will be the future, but it requires to be carefully done."

title: snp-mp-criticised-after-calling-for-striking-workers-to-keep-the-noise-down
story: Martyn Day raised concerns about ldquonoise disturbance during ldquounsociable hours during the dispute at the Bakkavor site in Borsquoness.However, the GMB union, which is representing the staff, hit back by saying that the only noise occurred during the working day.Staff at the plant, which is a major supplier of fresh produce to MS, have taken industrial action over what they regard as a ldquoderisory pay offer.Bakkavor have said that the .% increase is above inflation and have expressed disappointment at the unionrsquos actions.GMB members introduced an overtime ban in April, followed by three days of strike action. Another walk out is planned. Day, the MP for Linlithgow and East Falkirk since , has become embroiled in a spat with the union amid concerns about the conduct of the strike.In a letter to the GMB, he wrote that he supports the ldquoright of workers to strike for improved pay and conditions, but cautioned.ldquoI am writing to you on behalf of a number of constituents who have contacted me to raise concerns regarding noise disturbance from striking employees at Bakkavor in Borsquoness.Christina Lambie, an organiser with the union, responded: ldquoThe only noise today was between  and  AM and  and  PM and the last time I checked these are not unsocial hours."She added: ldquoResidents of the Bridgeness area could also help by writing to Bakkavor demanding that the matter be sorted. That would in my view be the best way to help avoid noisy protests.Labour MSP Neil Findlay said: "This is beyond belief. So much for solidarity with the workers from the SNP, Martyn Day needs to check his priorities.ldquoRather than asking the workers to keep quiet, he should have the courage to stand up to Bakkavor bosses and demand pay justice. Itrsquos nothing short of insulting, and the striking workers are due an apology.GMB Scotland Senior Organiser Louise Gilmour said:"Instead of asking workers to quiet down, Mr Day would be far better talking to them on the picket lines in an effort to actually understand why they are striking."If Mr Day agrees with the First Ministers aspirations to make Scotland a fair work nation then he should focus his efforts on getting Bakkavor back to talks and to deliver a living wage for its hard-pressed staff."A spokesperson for Day said: "Martyn Day fully supports the workers in their strike action at Bakkavor in Borsquoness over working conditions. He received a number of queries from his constituents and respectfully conveyed their views to the GMB.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Scotland really is leading the way on climate change  but it won t be a walk in the park
story: Therersquos some doubt, according to the science journal Nature, about just how effective tree planting is as a means of combating global warming. Trees emit chemicals too, and darken the land, thus absorbing heat. But letrsquos not quibble. The Committee on Climate Changewhich inspired last weekrsquos landmark target, is in no doubt that mass reforestation ndash and wersquore talking billions of trees ndash will be one of the major methods of scrubbing CO from the atmosphere.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeScotland is well placed to deliver on this at least. Those barren hills and glens used to be under a dense covering of foliage. The forests were cleared for agriculture and charcoal in the south, and latterly for sheep and deer in the north. So mass forestation is only restoring the ecological default in Scotland.Nice to know, too, that Scotland, on paper at least, is leading the way on meeting climate change targets, having reduced emissions by a creditable % since . This is better than the UK as a whole, which is itself a world-leader in climate control. Scotlandrsquos abundant renewable energy is going to play a major role in transforming the UK economy.Transport is one of the main areas yet to be decarbonised, and every watt of that green energy is needed to make the switch from petrol and diesel in the next decade. Itrsquos long overdue. The internal combustion engine is th-century technology, horribly complex, unreliable and inefficient. Future generations will be astonished that we allowed our city streets to remain sewers of toxic chemicals.Mind you, the Scottish Government needs to put its foot on the environmental accelerator pedal. It is three years since I wrote a series of articles on electric cars after being allowed to drive some of them around Scotland. There were precious few charging points back then, and therersquos scarcely any more now. Yet, the electrication of transport should be a relatively simple exercise.Every petrol station should be a charging station, every supermarket car park, every school and hospital. Wherever cars congregate, in fact. The good news is that no-one who tries a modern electric car will want to drive anything , because they are faster, cheaper, safer and more reliable.Of course, manufacturing any car uses prodigious amounts of energy too, requires many costly materials and produces toxic waste. Electric cars arenrsquot a solution to climate change, but electrication of transport must be, especially micro-transportation. Every city in Europe seem to be turning to those electric scooters ndash except in the UK where they are illegal. Half of the bicycles sold in Germany now are electric. People are turning naturally to more energy-efficient transport so why not give them a push :Climate clock is ticking and now is time for politicians to fightThe CCC report was rather benign on flying. Yoursquoll be pleased to know that itrsquos not being phased out. This is probably because reducing aviation requires international agreement. However, cuts in air passenger duty seem dficult to justy. The Scottish Government wants APD cut by % to attract more business and tourists to Scotland. But Nicola Sturgeon is going to have to bite the environmental bullet here. The optics are wrong. It looks too much like a middle-class subsidy, even though many working-class people swear by Ryanair.Then therersquos the nuclear conundrum. Scotlandrsquos nuclear power stations account for % of electricity generation ndash a large proportion of our nominally clean energy. But they are old and unreliable and in need of replacement. However, nuclear power stations are regardedas a safety issue following Fukushima. They are also ruinously expensive and damage the environment by producing toxic waste which needs to be stored for thousands of years.The nuclear industry leapt upon last weekrsquos CCC report as a vindication of nuclear as part of the de-carbon equation. Big money is going into painting the atom green. But the prospect of the Scottish Government commissioning a new nuclear plant, given the explosive cost of Hinkley Point C, Englandrsquos first new nuclear power station in decades, seem remote. Renewable energy is much cheaper, joule for joule,it can be brought to grid fast enough. We are in a race against time to seeTorness and Hunterston can be made redundant before they fall apart.There are other issues too. Homes need to be insulated, gas boilers are going to have to go. Wersquore told to keep our home thermostats at  degrees, when most of us donrsquot have them. Itrsquos all expected to cost -% of GDP. But what was remarkable about last weekrsquos much-anticipated report was how doable it all appeared. By comparison with the apocalyptic forecasts of the climate Cassandras, like -year-old school striker Greta Thunberg, the CCC sounded like a walk in the environmental park. Nicola Sturgeon insists that cutting carbon will improve our health and wellbeing and the quality of le. Wersquoll all be happier, cleaner and probably working less in our new habitable planet.I hope shersquos right. There was an air of wishful thinking about last weekrsquos pronouncements. But therersquos nothing wrong with accentuating the positive. The problem with the more alarmist forecasts of Extinction Rebellion, who want net zero by , is that they induce not willingness to change, but a sense of futility and public apathy. If addressing climate change is going to involve banning travel, eating no meat, digging for vegan victory and plunging the economy into a biblical recession, as we close down whole sectors of industry, then people will not buy into it. The Yellow Vest movement was ignited by an environmental tax.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeIt may well be that the climate change targets are still too conservative. According to the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change, CO emissions need to be cut faster to prevent the planet warming by more than .C ndash the new tipping point. But the Scottish and UK governments have consistently outperformed their targets since they started making them seriously over a decade ago. They can do so again.Much of climate hygiene is self-evident. The public are morally signed up to it, and while abandoning their petrol and diesel cars may seem a grim prospect now, in practice it is likely to be a liberation. Most cars spend their lives sitting near a pavement losing value through depreciation. With proper public transport and urban alternatives, everyone wins.Vested interests are always a block on progress, but there is now a remarkable consensus, from the CBI to the GMB, BP to the NFU, the BMA to BMW. Addressing climate change need not take us back to a pre-industrial world of squalor, disease and hardship. The human race isnrsquot over yet.
